threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
>What is this thread?
Every Wins'day at Win-O'-Clock we gather here and post links to the latest scans and rips of comic books.
Most links we uploaded ourselves, others we are sharing from elsewhere.
Some comics we've even purchased ourselves (but most we didn't).
If you'd like to help out, just ask and we would be delighted to tell you how.
Otherwise, be patient, be polite, and understand the simple concept behind these words: Not posted means not available yet.

>Where can I find old Win-O'-Threads?
http://desuarchive.org/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
http://boards.fireden.net/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
(Note: This finds the OP for old threads. If you want to search for comics in the archive, clear the subject field!)

>Where can I find downloads for other comics?
Warez forums/blogs, DDL-indexing search engines (like FilesLoop), torrent trackers (like 1337x) and other P2P networks (like DC++).
If a link has been posted on 4chan, you can search for it in the Desu archive (add "http*" to searches to return only posts with links).
If all else fails, just >buy it.

>Where can I buy comics?
http://www.amazon.com/
On the various publishers' webstores, and at your local comics shop.

>Where can I find an LCS?
http://www.comicshoplocator.com/

>Where can I find out when new comics are released?
http://www.comiclist.com/index.php
http://www.previewsworld.com

>How do I download from websites that only give me .exe files?
Untick the checkbox under the download button.

>How can I find this thread every week?
If you are using the inline extension go to http://4chan.org/co/official or use the option under "Filters & Post Hiding".
If you have 4chanX go to Settings > Filter > Subject and add the following line:
/Official Win-O'-Thread/;highlight

>And last but not least
Why's it dead?

I'm not 100% sure, but I think Leviathan was one of the first 2000AD books I actively sought out and bought full price (from Borders, which dates me a bit). It has its faults - I think an extra episode or two of more pure exploration of the Leviathan and investigation into the murders would have much improved the final story - but it's beautifully drawn, well written and never overstays its welcome. Hey all, my computer was acting like shit all week, and that combined with my work schedule and other life stuff, I fucked up and last thread died way too early.
https://desuarchive.org/co/thread/133959576/#133959576

For a reminder and newcomers, this is a thread where we're talking about ideas for 80s style cartoons w/ toylines we'd like to make, along with a focus on one story that gained a lot of traction in the first few threads: Stargaze and the Sentinels of Starlight.

The prompt was think of a story with a cool hero, a villain who gets foiled every episode and vows to get the hero next time, and a cast of supporting heroes and bad guys (nothing wrong with later 80s toon ideas breaking from that mold a bit though)

From that, we created the interstellar tech-using hero Stargaze aka prince Star-ro Blaster of Astray, along with his half-sister Comet of Tamau (concept art picrel).
Along with their faithful friend Lan-star, combat mentor Rock-it, warrior on a mission Conshock, shaman warrior and Star-ro's potential lady love Ursa-la, and the tricky con artist Shang-Xu; these Sentinels of the Stars work to protect the galaxy from the evil forces of: Wire Shark, tehnological the prison warden gone rogue and violent; Cicadra, the dominating Insect Queen bent on turning the world into her hive; Lan-star's slighted and power-hungry uncle Warmaster; the Nefarious cosmic entity Nebulius; and the ferocious technomancer Sigil with a mysterious connection to Comet!

Other toon ideas that came up that can be discussed: The 1920s Detective transported to a Fantasy Future; the Kick-Boxer who goes from local championships to intergalactic matches; and Girls in Black (like Men in Black but for girls).

See you, OUT THERE!

Capitalism isn't "just trading" though. That would be mercantilism or feudalism or some anarchist system. Capitalism codifies even abstract concepts like art and stocks into a complicated system of markets. You're not just trading you're also investing and speculating and insuring assets you already have or are getting. Those that own the most capital have the ability to snowball that into even more capital, creating the pseudo-monopolization and the 1% we have today.

And Dodge v Ford was meant to protect investors from an owner purposely sabotaging his own company and fucking them on dividends, which is what Ford was trying to do to the Dodge Brothers when they started taking their shares and dividends to build another company. Dodge v Ford is also rarely used in legal cases because it's niche.

Everything else is true. There needs to be a crash but capitalism isn't obligated to pay shareholders because of Dodge v Ford, it's because keeping investors happy is in your best interest for growing your company, or for giving yourself more money, and that means cutting costs which means cutting employee pay as much as you can.
